facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 1, 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Cr. Revision Case No. 403 of 1958 and Criminal Revision Petn. No. 337 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 1, 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Cr. Revision Case No. 403 of 1958 and Criminal Revision Petn. No. 337 of 1957.

facts.text: The appellant was convicted under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code by the Assistant Sessions Judge of Kurnool.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code by the Assistant Sessions Judge of Kurnool.

facts.text: Hussain Saheb was tried and convicted under s. 457 and 380 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Along with him, another person Hussain Saheb was also tried and was companyvicted under so. 457 and 380 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: The house of Ramayya in Dudyia was burgled on the night of April 20, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The case for the prosecution briefly was that the house of Rahayya in Dudyia was burgied on the night of April 20, 1957.

facts.text: Ramayya and his wife were sleeping outside and found the house burgled and valuable property stolen in the morning.

anchor.surface_text: Ramayya and his wife were sleeping outside and on waking in the morning they found that the house had been burgled and valuable property stolen.

facts.text: The matter was reported to the police.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was reported to the police and during the companyrse of investigation the police recovered 17 ornaments

facts.text: Police recovered 17 ornaments on the information given by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: during the companyrse of investigation the police recovered 17 ornaments on the information given by the appellant.

facts.text: The other accused gave information on the basis of which another stolen ornament was recovered.

anchor.surface_text: The other accused had also given information on the basis of which another stolen ornament was recovered.

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge concluded that the other accused committed house breaking, removed ornaments from Ramayya's house and handed over 17 to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Sessions Judge on a companysideration of the evidence came to the companyclusion that the other accused had actually companymitted house breaking and had removed ornaments from the house of Ramayya and had handed over 17 ornaments out of that property to the appellant.

facts.text: Assistant Sessions Judge found appellant guilty under s. 411 IPC as ornaments were in his possession.

anchor.surface_text: He also came to the companyclusion that the seventeen ornaments recovered at the instance of the appellant were in his possession and he therefore found him guilty under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant and other accused appealed to Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and the other accused went in appeal to the Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted appellant, holding recovery from accessible garden and inadmissible statement did not prove possession.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge held that the appellant had number been proved to be in possession of the seventeen ornaments which were recovered at his instance from a garden. ... it companyld number be held that the ornaments were in the appellants possession. He therefore gave the benefit of doubt to the appellant and ordered his acquittal.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted the other accused.

anchor.surface_text: He also acquitted the other accused at whose instance one of the stolen ornaments was recovered.

facts.text: Ramayya filed revision against appellant and other accused.

anchor.surface_text: This was followed by a revision by Ramayya against the appellant and the other accused.

facts.text: High Court allowed the revision and directed retrial by Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has allowed the revision and directed that the matter should go back to the Sessions Judge so that the accused should be re-tried on the charges on which they had been brought to trial on the former occasion.

facts.text: Only Chinnaswamy Reddy appealed to Supreme Court, other accused did not.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned, however, that only Chinnaswamy Reddy has appealed while the other accused has number appealed against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: 17 ornaments recovered from garden at appellant's instance; he stated he had hidden them there.

anchor.surface_text: The statement of the appellant in this respect was that he would show the place where he had hidden them  the ornaments . Thereafter he went to the garden and dug out two bundles companytaining the seventeen ornaments from there.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held appellant's statement that he hid the ornaments inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge held that that part of the statement of the appellant where he said that he had hidden the ornaments was number admissible in evidence.

facts.text: Other accused stated he gave ornament to Bada Sab and recovered from him.

anchor.surface_text: This accused had stated that he given the ornaments to Bada Sab W. 5  and took the police party to Bada Sab and asked him to return the ornaments, which Bada Sab did.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on July 25, 1962 by WANCHOO, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. July 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court held the entire statement of appellant admissible under s. 27 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: The whole of this statement in our opinion relates distinctly to the discovery of ornaments and is admissible under s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court order for retrial and directed Sessions Judge to rehear the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal subject to the modification indicated above.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 1, 1959, of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Cr. Revision Case No. 403 of 1958 and Criminal Revision Petn. No. 337 of 1957.
The appellant was convicted under s. 411 of the Indian Penal Code by the Assistant Sessions Judge of Kurnool.

anchor.surface_text: The extent of the jurisdiction of the High Court in the matter of interfering in revision against an order of acquittal has been considered by this Court on a number of occasions. In D, Stephens v. Nosibolla  1  this Court observed- The revisional jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is not to be lightly exer- cised when it in invoked by a private complainant against an order of acquittal

concepts.interpretation: Interference justified only in exceptional cases: no jurisdiction, wrongly shut out evidence, wrongly held admissible evidence inadmissible, overlooked material evidence, invalid compounding; here applicable as Sessions Judge wrongly held part of statement inadmissible under S.27.

issues.text: whether the order of the High Court setting aside the order of acquittal in this case can be upheld on these principles

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore to see whether the order of the High Court setting aside the order of acquittal in this case can be upheld on these principles. A perusal of the judgment of the High Court shows that the High Court has gone into the evidence in great detail so far as the case against the appellant was concerned.

issues.text: whether the statement of the appellant to the effect that he had hidden the ornaments and would point out the place where they were, is wholly admissible in evidence under s. 27 or only that part of it is admissible where he stated that he would point out the place but not that part where he stated that he had hidden the ornaments

anchor.surface_text: Let us then turn to the question whether the statement of the appellant to the effect that ,he had hidden them  the ornaments  and would point out the place where they were, is wholly admissible in evidence under s. 27 or only that part of it is admissible where he stated that he would point out the place but number that part where he stated that he had hidden the ornaments.

issues.text: whether the appeal court should be ordered to re-hear the appeal after admitting the statement it had ruled out or whether there should necessarily be a retrial
whether there were exceptional circumstances which would justify the High Court in interfering with an order of acquittal at the instance of a private party

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellant before us is that this was a revision by a private party. There were no exceptional circumstances in this case which would justify the High Court in interfering with an order of acquittal at the instance of a private party.

arguments.claim: There were no exceptional circumstances in this case which would justify the High Court in interfering with an order of acquittal at the instance of a private party.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the appellant before us is that this was a revision by a private party. There were no exceptional circumstances in this case which would justify the High Court in interfering with an order of acquittal at the instance of a private party.

arguments.claim: Section 439(4) CrPC specifically forbids the High Court from converting a finding of acquittal into one of conviction, and ordering retrial indirectly converts acquittal to conviction.

anchor.surface_text: Further, it is urged that s. 439(4) of the Code of Criminal Procedure specifically forbids the High Court from converting a finding of acquittal into one of conviction and that a reading of the judgment of the High Court shows that by the indirect method of retrial the High Court has practically directed the Sessions Court to convict the appellant

arguments.claim: Revisional jurisdiction under s.439 CrPC not to be lightly exercised by private complainant against acquittal; only in exceptional cases like manifest illegality or gross miscarriage of justice.

arguments.claim: High Court cannot convert acquittal to conviction even indirectly by ordering retrial if it amounts to loading the dice against accused.

anchor.surface_text: Though sub-s.(1) of s.439 of the Criminal Procedure Code authorises the High Court to exercise in its discretion any of the powers conferred on a court of appeal by s.423, yet sub-s.(4) specifically excludes the power to convert a finding of acquittal into one of conviction.

arguments.claim: Where appellate court wrongly excludes evidence admitted by trial court and full record exists, proper course is to direct rehearing of appeal, not retrial.

anchor.surface_text: Where, as in this case, the entire evidence is there and it was the appeal court which ruled out the evidence that had been admitted by the trial court, the proper course in our opinion is to send back the appeal for rehearing to the appeal court.

arguments.court_reasoning: Trial court conviction stands subject to rehearing; avoids prejudice of retrial.

arguments.claim: Ornaments recovered from accessible garden; without admissible statement proving appellant hid them, no possession proved under s.411 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge held that the appellant had not been proved to be in possession of the seventeen ornaments which were recovered at his instance from a garden. ... Therefore, he took the view that as the ornaments were recovered from a place which was accessible to all and sundry and there was no other evidence to show that the appellant had hidden them, it could not be held that the ornaments were in the appellants possession.

holdings.text: High Court justified in interfering with acquittal in revision as Sessions Judge wrongly ruled out admissible evidence under s.27 Evidence Act, which is an exceptional circumstance.

anchor.surface_text: If therefore this part of the statement of the appellant and the other accused which led to discovery of ornaments is admissible, it must be held that the appeal court wrongly ruled out evidence which was admissible. In these circumstances, the case would clearly be covered by the principles we have set out above in as much as relevant evidence was ruled out as inadmissible and the High Court would be justified in interfering with the order of acquittal so that the evidence may be reappraised after taking into account the evidence which was wrongly ruled out as inadmissible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied doctrine of exceptional cases for revisional interference (citing Stephens and Logendranath); here appellate court misapplied s.27, excluding trial-admitted evidence.

holdings.text: High Court should not deal with evidence in detail when ordering retrial, as it loads the dice against accused.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the judgment of the High Court shows that the High Court has gone into the evidence in great detail so far as the case against the appellant was concerned. In our opinion, the High Court should not have dealt with evidence in such detail when it was going to order a retrial, for such detailed consideration of evidence, as pointed out in Logendranaths case amounts to loading the dice against the appellant, when the case goes back for retrial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed Logendranath Jha: detailed evidence review in revision before retrial prejudices accused.

holdings.text: Entire statement of appellant ('he had hidden the ornaments and would point out the place') relates distinctly to discovery and is wholly admissible under s.27 Evidence Act.

anchor.surface_text: The whole of this statement in our opinion relates distinctly to the discovery of ornaments and is admissible under s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act. The words where he had hidden them are not on a par with the words with which I stabbed the deceased in the example given in the judgment of the Judicial Committee.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpreted s.27: info distinctly related to discovery admissible even if confessional; distinguished Pulukuri Kottaya as words here integral to discovery, not past history.

holdings.text: Where appellate court wrongly excludes evidence admitted by trial court and full record exists, direct rehearing of appeal by appellate court, not retrial by trial court.

anchor.surface_text: Where, as in this case, the entire evidence is there and it was the appeal court which ruled out the evidence that had been admitted by the trial court, the proper course in our opinion is to send back the appeal for rehearing to the appeal court. In such a case the order of the trial court would stand subject to the decision of the appeal court on re-hearing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural efficiency and fairness: avoids retrial prejudice when evidence complete; trial conviction revivable on rehearing.

holdings.text: Appeal allowed; High Court order modified to direct Sessions Judge to rehear appeal without being influenced by High Court observations on evidence.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal subject to the modification indicated above. ... We should like to add that the appeal court when it re-hears the appeal should not be influenced by any observations of the High Court on the appreciation of the evidence and should bring to bear its own mind on the evidence after taking into consideration that part of the evidence which was, considered inadmissible previously by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ultimate disposition applying above holdings; modifies to prevent prejudice.

holdings.text: s.439(4) CrPC prohibits High Court from converting acquittal to conviction directly or indirectly via retrial that loads dice against accused.

anchor.surface_text: Though sub-s.(1) of s.439 ... specifically excludes the power to convert a finding of acquittal into one of conviction. ... Sub-section (4) of s.439 forbids a High Court from converting a finding of acquittal into one of conviction and that makes it all the more incumbent on the High Court to see that it does not convert the finding of acquittal into one of conviction by the indirect method of ordering retrial

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation confirmed by precedent (Logendranath); limits revisional power.

anchor.surface_text: D, Stephens v. Nosibolla  1  this Court observed- The revisional jurisdiction companyferred on the High Court under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is number to be lightly exer- cised when it in invoked by a private companyp- lainant against an order of acquittal, against which the Government has a right of appeal under a. 417. It companyld be exercised only  1  1951 S.C.R. 284.

precedents.cited_proposition: Limits of High Court's revisional jurisdiction against acquittal when invoked by private party: not to be lightly exercised, only in exceptional cases involving manifest illegality or gross miscarriage of justice
precedents.cited_holding: The revisional jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under s. 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is not to be lightly exercised when it is invoked by a private complainant against an order of acquittal [...] only in exceptional cases where the interests of public justice require interference for the correction of a manifest illegality or the prevention of a gross miscarriage of justice.

precedents.citation: Logendranath Jha v. Shri Polailal Biswas 1 1951 S.C.R. 676

anchor.surface_text: Logendranath Jha v. Shri Polailal Biswas 1 , this Court observed- Though sub-s.  1  of s. 439 of the Criminal Procedure Code authorises the High Court to exercise in its discretion any of the powers companyferred on a companyrt of appeal by s. 423, yet sub-s.  4  specifically excludes the power to companyvert a finding of acquittal into one of companyviction.

precedents.case_name: Logendranath Jha v Shri Polailal Biswas
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court cannot convert acquittal into conviction directly or indirectly via retrial in revision by private party; cannot reappraise evidence and reverse findings of fact
precedents.cited_holding: Though sub-s. (1) of s. 439 [...] authorises the High Court to exercise [...] powers conferred on a court of appeal by s. 423, yet sub-s. (4) specifically excludes the power to convert a finding of acquittal into one of conviction. This does not mean that [...] the High Court can [...] reappraise the evidence and reverse the findings of facts on which the acquittal was based, provided only it stops short of finding the accused guilty [...] by ordering a re-trial.

precedents.citation: Pulukuri Kotayya v. King-Emperor 2 1946 L.R. 74 I.A. 65

anchor.surface_text: Pulukuri Kotayya v. King-Emperor  2  where a part of the statement leading to the recovery of a knife in a murder case was held inadmissible by the Judicial Committee. In that case the Judicial Committee companysidered s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act [...] so much of such information [...] as relates distinctly to the fact thereby discovered, may be proved.

precedents.cited_proposition: Scope of admissibility under s.27 Evidence Act: only so much of information as relates distinctly to the fact discovered; information as to past user or history not related to discovery
precedents.cited_holding: The extent of the information admissible must depend on the exact nature of the fact discovered to which such information is required to relate. [...] Information as to past user, or the past history of the object produced is not related to its discovery [...]. Information supplied [...] 'I will produce a knife concealed in the roof of my house' leads to the discovery [...] but if added 'with which I stabbed A', those words are inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: particular, Logendranath Jhas case  1  stresses that it is number open to a High Court to companyvert a finding of acquittal into one of companyviction in view of the provisions of s. 439 (4) and that the High Court cannot do this even indirectly by ordering re-trial.

precedents.case_name: Logendranath Jha v Shri Polailal Biswas
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court cannot convert acquittal to conviction even indirectly by ordering retrial

anchor.surface_text: the High Court should number have dealt with evidence in such detail when it was going to order a retrial, for such detailed companysideration of evidence, as pointed out in Logendranaths case  1  amounts to loading the dice against the appellant

precedents.case_name: Logendranath Jha v Shri Polailal Biswas
precedents.cited_proposition: Detailed consideration of evidence by High Court when ordering retrial loads the dice against accused

anchor.surface_text: Unfortunately, the High Court went further and appraised the evidence also which it should number have done, as held by this Court in Logendranaths case.

precedents.case_name: Logendranath Jha v Shri Polailal Biswas
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court should not appraise evidence when ordering retrial in revision against acquittal

justification_sets.label: Natural Justice - Audi Alteram Partem support

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the proper course is to direct the appeal court to re-hear the appeal and either maintain the conviction after taking into consideration the evidence which was ruled out by it previously or to acquit the accused if that is the just course to take. We should like to add that the appeal court when it re-hears the appeal should not be influenced by any observations of the High Court on the appreciation of the evidence and should bring to bear its own mind on the evidence after taking into consideration that part of the evidence which was, considered inadmissible previously by it. We therefore allow the appeal subject to the modification indicated above.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed subject to modification; High Court order of retrial set aside and Sessions Judge directed to re-hear the appeal considering admissible evidence under s.27 Evidence Act
directions: Sessions Judge (appeal court) to re-hear the appeal
Take into consideration the previously ruled out part of accused's statement as admissible under s.27
Maintain conviction or acquit as just after independent appreciation
Not to be influenced by High Court's observations on evidence

anchor.surface_text: If therefore this part of the statement of the appellant and the other accused which led to discovery of ornaments is admissible, it must be held that the appeal court wrongly ruled out evidence which was admissible. In these circumstances, the case would clearly be covered by the principles we have set out above in as much as relevant evidence was ruled out as inadmissible and the High Court would be justified in interfering with the order of acquittal so that the evidence may be reappraised after taking into account the evidence which was wrongly ruled out as inadmissible.
n the ornament to Bada Sab, he did number companysistently with what be said with respect to the appellant, attach importance to this statement of the

edges.explanation: holding identifies exceptional circumstance (wrong exclusion of s.27 evidence), resolving the issue of exceptional justification

anchor.surface_text: In the circumstances we are of opinion that the proper course is to direct the appeal court to re-hear the appeal and either maintain the conviction after taking into consideration the evidence which was ruled out by it previously or to acquit the accused if that is the just course to take. We should like to add that the appeal court when it re-hears the appeal should not be influenced by any observations of the High Court on the appreciation of the evidence and should bring to bear its own mind on the evidence after taking into consideration that part of the evidence which was, considered inadmissible previously by it. We therefore allow the appeal subject to the modification indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: A perusal of the judgment of the High Court shows that the High Court has gone into the evidence in great detail so far as the case against the appellant was concerned. In our opinion, the High Court should not have dealt with evidence in such detail when it was going to order a retrial, for such detailed consideration of evidence, as pointed out in Logendranaths case amounts to loading the dice against the appellant, when the case goes back for retrial.

In the circumstances we are of opinion that the proper course is to direct the appeal court to re-hear the appeal and either maintain the conviction after taking into consideration the evidence which was ruled out by it previously or to acquit the accused if that is the just course to take. We should like to add that the appeal court when it re-hears the appeal should not be influenced by any observations of the High Court on the appreciation of the evidence and should bring to bear its own mind on the evidence after taking into consideration that part of the evidence which was, considered inadmissible previously by it. We therefore allow the appeal subject to the modification indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: The whole of this statement in our opinion relates distinctly to the discovery of ornaments and is admissible under s. 27 of the Indian Evidence Act. The words where he had hidden them are not on a par with the words with which I stabbed the deceased in the example given in the judgment of the Judicial Committee.

In the circumstances we are of opinion that the proper course is to direct the appeal court to re-hear the appeal and either maintain the conviction after taking into consideration the evidence which was ruled out by it previously or to acquit the accused if that is the just course to take. We should like to add that the appeal court when it re-hears the appeal should not be influenced by any observations of the High Court on the appreciation of the evidence and should bring to bear its own mind on the evidence after taking into consideration that part of the evidence which was, considered inadmissible previously by it. We therefore allow the appeal subject to the modification indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: Where, as in this case, the entire evidence is there and it was the appeal court which ruled out the evidence that had been admitted by the trial court, the proper course in our opinion is to send back the appeal for rehearing to the appeal court. In such a case the order of the trial court would stand subject to the decision of the appeal court on re-hearing.

In the circumstances we are of opinion that the proper course is to direct the appeal court to re-hear the appeal and either maintain the conviction after taking into consideration the evidence which was ruled out by it previously or to acquit the accused if that is the just course to take. We should like to add that the appeal court when it re-hears the appeal should not be influenced by any observations of the High Court on the appreciation of the evidence and should bring to bear its own mind on the evidence after taking into consideration that part of the evidence which was, considered inadmissible previously by it. We therefore allow the appeal subject to the modification indicated above.

In the circumstances we are of opinion that the proper course is to direct the appeal court to re-hear the appeal and either maintain the conviction after taking into consideration the evidence which was ruled out by it previously or to acquit the accused if that is the just course to take. We therefore allow the appeal subject to the modification indicated above.
